Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Publishers, Translators, and the Circulation of Western Texts in Iran

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Yale University doctoral candidate Hosna Sheikholeslami, with the guidance of Dr. Karen Nakamura, will undertake research on how and why social scientific and philosophical ideas travel across cultures. Her particular focus will be the role of publishers and translators in the promotion of selected theories and thinkers; she will investigate the process that surround the selection, translation, publication, dissemination, and acceptance of introduced texts.

The research is to be conducted in Tehran, Iran. The researcher will employ a wide range of social science research methods including semi-structured interviews, participant observation, career story interviews, life history interviews, cognitive science methodologies, media analysis, archival research, and intensive study of translations. Focusing on four major publishing houses, data will be gathered from current and former publishers, translators, editors, intellectuals, censors, bureaucrats, printers, distributors, bookstore owners, reviewers, and readers.

The research is important because it will be one of the first systematic studies to add the processes of translation and publication to theories of how knowledge circulates across societal and cultural boundaries. Findings from this research will contribute important information about the circulation of Western ideas and texts in Islamic societies. Funding this research also supports the education of a graduate student.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Publishers, Translators, and the Circulation of Western Texts in Iran was a 24-month ethnographic study of the Iranian publishing and translation industries asking how and why ideas travel by tracing the circulation of translated texts of Western philosophy and social science in Iran. The study endeavored to answer the following questions: How and why do translators and publishers in Iran select certain texts for translation and publication? 

To this end, the researcher carried out 90 interviews (on occasion, multiple interviews were conducted with the same person over time). Key informants included translators, publishers, public intellectuals, students, editors, distributors, and bookstore owners. The researcher also conducted participant observation in two major publishing houses. She attended the 10-day long Tehran International Book Fair for two consecutive years, maintained involvement with an organized group of women publishers, was a participating member of a weekly gathering of intellectuals at a publishing house, and attended relevant public classes and workshops. She also carried a comparative study of the translation scene between Tehran and Qom, located and examined the laws for publishing since 2006, and collected quantitative data on book production in Iran.

The researcher learned that addressing the availability of books on the market, as selected by translators and publishers, required a broad understanding of the social transmission of knowledge in Iran. Thus, rather than focusing on book content, the researcher found that it is impossible to understand the circulation of certain books in the Iranian public sphere without attending to the economics, politics, social networks, and theoretical debates that shape publishers’ and translators’ decisions. She identified a number of factors that enable, limit, or otherwise shape publishers’ and translators’ selection choices: 1) publisher’s and translators’ social networks, 2) the political economy of the book market, 3) the cultural politics of the Iranian state, and 4) debates on the status of social science translation in Iran, which includes questions of content.  

As a result of this research, the researcher found that there is a growing reflexivity and critical awareness on the part of these actors in regards to their decision making process. This critical awareness can be enhanced by and through state policies. The researcher argues that vis-à-vis the contestation around books, we can observe some of the major debates around public law in Iran. Public law is the modern expression of the medieval European notion of fundamental law. This is the law that establishes the relation of the sovereign to the state, or more specifically, that body of law which forms the basis for the emergence of an autonomous public sphere. Thus, the realm of books is one of negotiations over the power and place of the sovereign in Iran. She discovered that the development of critical thinking in the public sphere is tied to contestations surrounding public law in Iran. 

This project seeks to make a contribution to the anthropology of knowledge and political anthropology. In doing so, the researcher provide methodological suggestions for the study of knowledge and intellectuals via ethnographic methods. By utilizing the concept of public law, she hopes to open up new horizons for political anthropology. Ultimately, the researcher argues that the strength of civil society, or the public sphere, and the state are mutually linked.
